title: After smashing Bahamas, Hurricane Dorian threatens southeastern U.S.
text:
Forecasts show Hurricane Dorian menacing Georgia and the Carolinas.

The storm pulverized the Bahamas, where the death toll is expected to rise.

Hurricane and flood warnings stretched across the southeastern U.S. coastline.

After devastating part of the Bahamas, Hurricane Dorian kept rumbling north on Wednesday and was forecast to stay dangerously close to a wide swath of the southeastern United States. Forecasters say that while the storm is gradually leaving Florida behind, it threatens the coasts of Georgia and the Carolinas with dangerous wind, rain and storm surges.

Hurricane Dorian projected to stay ‘dangerously close’ to southeast

As Hurricane Dorian continues moving north, it is forecast to keep moving “dangerously close to the southeast U.S. coast,” the National Hurricane Center reported late Wednesday afternoon.

Tropical storm conditions are impacting the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina, the hurricane center reported. The Capital Weather Gang has warned that the severity of Dorian’s impact will be linked to how closely the storm tracks to the coast — and warned that the Georgia and South Carolina coastlines are particularly vulnerable to storm surge flooding, even if the storm doesn’t make landfall.

The National Hurricane Center said late Wednesday afternoon that the storm’s “track is close to and almost parallel to the coast of the southeastern United States, and any deviation to the left of the track could bring the center onshore anywhere in the Carolinas.”

But regardless of where Dorian’s center goes, the hurricane center said, “life-threatening storm surge and dangerous winds are expected” to be an issue along the coasts of Florida, Georgia, the Carolinas and Virginia. Flash flooding is projected to become increasingly likely in coastal Georgia and the eastern Carolinas from Wednesday night into Friday, the center said.

Follow the Capital Weather Gang for the latest forecasts.

— Mark Berman

Trump appearance again spotlights ‘Alabama’ issue

As Hurricane Dorian made its way from the Bahamas and toward the U.S. East Coast, President Trump injected politics into his administration’s response twice within a span of 24 hours.

On Tuesday night, the president tweeted that he was signing an emergency declaration for North Carolina at the request of Sen. Thom Tillis (N.C.), a fellow Republican who is up for reelection next year and who has won Trump’s backing amid a stiff primary challenge. But the declaration was actually requested by North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat.

Then, on Wednesday afternoon, Trump displayed what appeared to be a doctored map during a hurricane briefing with officials in the Oval Office. The map showed a white line encircling the area likely to be affected by Hurricane Dorian — as well as a black line, not seen on previous maps, intersecting with part of the state of Alabama.

Trump had been sharply criticized Sunday for a tweet in which he claimed, incorrectly, that Alabama was among the states that would be hit “harder than anticipated” by the storm.

[President Trump showed a doctored hurricane chart. Was it to cover up for ‘Alabama’ Twitter flub?]

Among those pushing back against Trump’s tweet was the National Weather Service in Birmingham, Ala., which tweeted that the state would “NOT see any impacts” from Hurricane Dorian.

As reporters pressed him for answers later Wednesday, Trump maintained that he had previously been told there was a “95 percent” probability that Alabama would be hit by the hurricane. He denied any knowledge of whether anyone had drawn on the map, saying only, “I don’t know. I don’t know. I don’t know.”

A White House spokesman did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

— Felicia Sonmez and John Wagner

North Carolina governor asks residents to get ready for Dorian, reports death linked to storm preparation

North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper (D) reported what he described Wednesday as “our state’s first storm-related death.” An 85-year-old man fell from a ladder in Columbus County while preparing his home for the storm, Cooper said at a news briefing.

Cooper said that Thursday would bring a high risk of flash flooding to parts of the state, and he urged residents to get ready and to do so carefully.

“Today is the day to finish preparing,” he said. “And I urge everyone to do so with safety in mind.”

— Mark Berman

The threat facing the Carolinas

From the Capital Weather Gang: Hurricane Dorian had originally been advertised as a huge threat to the Florida coastline, but it seems more likely now that it will be remembered both for the devastation it caused in the Bahamas, as well as the storm-surge flooding it might bring to the Carolinas. Water levels are already rising along the coasts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. Some locations may see as much as five to eight feet of storm-surge flooding, which will come on top of already high astronomical high tides. Storm surge refers to the storm-driven rise in ocean water above normally dry land.

Read more here.

‘We have not seen a hurricane of this kind in the country ever before’

The scale of the devastation in the Bahamas was still coming into focus Wednesday, said Theo Neilly, consul general for the Bahamas in Washington. But what has emerged has been overwhelming, with “extremely severe” damage and flooding seen on the Great Abaco island, where the airport and neighborhoods were left underwater.

“We have not seen a hurricane of this kind in the country ever before,” Neilly said in an interview.

Neilly said that Prime Minister Hubert Minnis, who took an aerial tour of Great Abaco, was preparing Wednesday afternoon to go to Grand Bahama for an assessment of the damage there.

Minnis has said that officials have confirmed seven deaths, but he said that they expect that number to increase. Authorities are not releasing an updated death toll until they can confirm the numbers, Neilly said.

Grand Bahama was only becoming accessible Wednesday to ships and helicopters, Neilly said. He also expressed particular worry that the storm ravaged some of the most populated areas of the Bahamian archipelago.

“One thing that concerns us and to keep in mind is, Grand Bahama is … the second-largest population in the Bahamas,” Neilly said. “Abaco is the third-largest population. And a large portion of the economy as well.”

Neilly said he sympathized with people struggling in the wake of the storm, noting that he lived through Hurricane Andrew strafing the Bahamas in 1992. Neilly said that in 1992, when Andrew hit, he was in Current, an island town ravaged by the storm. (Neilly said he believed that “the damage was so extensive I think about 80 percent of the town was destroyed at the time.” In a Washington Post story at the time, a reporter wrote that most of Current’s few hundred homes were “reduced to piles of timber and shattered glass.”)

“It’s so hard,” Neilly said. “I went through Hurricane Andrew myself as a teenager. It just brings back so many memories of feeling isolated, feeling that sometimes the supplies and relief effort didn’t come quick enough.”

He said these supplies and relief are coming, but he recalled that in his experience, “everything just seems longer than it is” in the aftermath of a storm. Neilly said officials are trying to provide relief as rapidly as possible.

“Many families, many people have lost all they have,” Neilly said. “So it’s important we get in there as quickly as we can to provide relief for them.”

Neilly praised the help provided by the United States, noting that the U.S. Coast Guard has been evacuating people from the Bahamas. He also said authorities were moved by the response of big countries along with officials from smaller nations and territories, including Dominica and Puerto Rico, which have been hit by storms recently and are still reaching out to offer help.

In Washington, Neilly said he has been helping collect supplies to send to Miami and on to the Bahamas. He also said they were fielding calls from the Bahamian diaspora in the United States, seeking information on their loved ones as well as hoping to send supplies, along with calls from lawmakers, other countries and nongovernmental organizations sending support and offering assistance.

“You can imagine how seriously I take it,” he said. “Because I’ve been through it.”

— Mark Berman

In Nassau, mounting frustration as many await news

NASSAU, Bahamas — Family members have gathered at the helicopter terminal of Nassau’s international airport awaiting evacuees from the Abacos islands. Ralanda McKinney, a 25-year-old Abacos transplant living in Nassau, was waiting for news of her parents, who live in the Abacos neighborhood of Treasure Cay.

Their neighbor who was evacuated with severe injuries had told her that he had seen them at a shelter that was running out of food.

“I don’t care about possessions,” McKinney said. “I just want to see their faces.”

At the helicopter terminal, Bahamians were becoming increasingly frustrated with the official response.

Rayven Bootle, 18, was waiting for word from her mother, grandmother and others in Treasure Cay. She said the Abacos community in Nassau had organized donations of water, food and toiletries but the government was preventing them from taking them there.

“It’s been days. Dorian is gone,” she said. “Come on, we need to get in.”

— Anthony Faiola

Trump says ‘we certainly got lucky in Florida’

In the Oval Office Wednesday afternoon, President Trump was briefed about the hurricane by officials including acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan and Adm. Karl Schultz, commandant of the U.S. Coast Guard.

“We certainly got lucky in Florida. … We’ll see what happens, but it’s a very erratic, very slow, very powerful hurricane,” Trump said. He added: “It looks like Florida is going to be in fantastic shape, in comparison to what we thought.”

The president also maintained that the federal government is “very well-prepared” for whatever course the hurricane takes.

— Felicia Sonmez

They dodged Dorian. Now some Floridians question the evacuation orders.

JACKSONVILLE — In Jacksonville’s upscale San Marco neighborhood, residents were under a mandatory evacuation order, and many homeowners had wedged sandbags against doorways amid fears that the St. Johns River could flood. But on Wednesday afternoon, the weather was still calm enough that fishermen were lining the bulkhead.

“There isn’t nothing coming this way,” said Jerome Owens, 57, who was using a croaker as bait in hopes of catching a red fish. “It’s high tide, and the water is supposed to be coming over, but all we got is some rain showers.”

“Man, my neighbor is home cutting his lawn right now,” added Gary Williams, 66. “And if you go to the other side of town, you can probably find people having barbecues in their front lawn.”

Occasional gusts of wind did buffet Jacksonville — strong enough to blow over the folding chairs being used by the fishermen. But as dolphins fed in the river, Williams and Owens said local officials had overreacted by ordering the evacuation of a quarter million Jacksonville residents.

“They made too big of deal about this storm, and they should have known when it just stopped and sat over the Bahamas that it wasn’t going to make it here to be anything like Irma,” said Owens, referring to Hurricane Irma, which flooded nearly 1,000 properties here in 2017.

Some residents in Jacksonville Beach, a barrier island along the Atlantic Ocean, also questioned city leaders decision to order such a broader evacuation order. The mandatory evacuation order went into effect Monday morning, more than a day before the storm’s expected arrival.

Jacksonville Mayor Lenny Curry (R) strongly defended his decision, noting it takes 48 hours to successfully evacuate a quarter million people. “This is my third storm in four years,” Curry said. “We know what we are doing.”

— Tim Craig

FEMA sends teams across the Southeast

With the threat posed by Hurricane Dorian seemingly stretching across the Southeast, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, or FEMA, responded by deploying all across the region.

In a situation report early Wednesday, FEMA reported that it had emergency operations centers established in five states: Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Virginia. That expanse covered both the places that dodged the worst of Dorian’s wrath (Florida), the next areas on edge (Georgia and the Carolinas) and then the northernmost state still awaiting the storm (Virginia).

FEMA’s response to some disasters has been criticized in the past, including by auditors in the Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general’s office. The situation report provided a small glimpse of how FEMA deployed its resources with the storm’s forecast uncertain.

Mobile emergency response support teams had been deployed in the Carolinas, Georgia, Florida and Puerto Rico, according to the situation report. Staging teams were dispatched to Alabama, South Carolina and North Carolina, and other staging areas and field locations dotted the Southeast. There were also other teams and resources sent across these states and Puerto Rico, which had warily awaited Dorian before escaping the worst of the storm.

— Mark Berman

‘One of the greatest national crises in our country’s history'

NASSAU, Bahamas — Houses torn open. Cars, boats and heavy equipment tossed and crumpled. Whole communities flooded, and flattened. Seven dead, according to the official count, and more expected.

The government in this nation of 400,000 sounded the all-clear from Hurricane Dorian Wednesday morning, lifting the tropical storm warning for Grand Bahama, the Abacos, Bimini and other battered islands.



Mister Bolter recovers dishes from his son's home, destroyed by Hurricane Dorian in Pine Bay, near Freeport, Bahamas, Wednesday, Sept. 4, 2019. Rescuers trying to reach drenched and stunned victims in the Bahamas fanned out across a blasted landscape of smashed and flooded homes Wednesday, while disaster relief organizations rushed to bring in food and medicine. (Ramon Espinosa)

As the storm, which slammed into the Bahamas Sunday as a Category 5 hurricane and spent a devastating 40 hours grinding across Grand Bahama, finally lurched onward to the United States, the full scope of the destruction became clearer.

“We are in the midst of one of the greatest national crises in our country’s history,” Prime Minister Hubert Minnis said Tuesday night.

Read more here.

— Anthony Faiola and Maria Sacchetti

In Florida, relief mixed with sympathy for the Bahamas

Dorian arrived offshore of Dayton Beach and its surrounding counties with a thud on Wednesday morning, leaving little damage and rainfall no worse than the occasional storm earlier in the week.

Bridges shut down for high wind on Tuesday night reopened earlier than expected Wednesday morning. Shelters reopened less than an hour later. Few cars were on the roads, and few businesses were open. Residents who lived by the beach or in flood zones said it was hard to tell a hurricane was even close, wobbling offshore.

“It’s a rainy day, and that’s about all I can say,” said Eileen Keenan, who chose to stay in her house a block away from the beach.

With her lights still on, Keenan said her only problem was not being able to get her daily Starbucks because the coffee chain, like many other businesses, shut their doors for the day. But like many, she looked at the near miss and felt sympathy for those in the Bahamas who took the full brunt of the storm.

“We can joke about it and be like ‘ugh,’ but you have to be grateful that nothing happened, and we were not the Bahamas. Good god, help those poor people,” said Keenan, 53.

— Fenit Nirappil

Hurricane Dorian moving ‘almost parallel’ to the southeastern U.S. coast

The storm has stayed far enough from the Florida coast to spare that state the worst of its wrath, but a more significant impact is expected in Georgia and the Carolinas, according to forecasters.

The Capital Weather Gang reported Wednesday that the impact could be damaging in areas including Charleston, S.C., where water levels could reach some of the highest recorded, and the Outer Banks in North Carolina, where high winds could lead to damage and power outages.

[City by city forecasts in the Southeast United States]

In a late-morning bulletin Wednesday, the National Hurricane Center said the storm was expected to move “parallel to the Florida east coast and the Georgia coast” through the evening. Then, it warned, the storm’s center was projected to move near or over the coast of the Carolinas on Thursday and into Friday. But even if the center remains offshore, the storm could still deliver a punishing blow.

“Life-threatening storm surge and dangerous winds are expected along portions of the Florida east coast and the coasts of Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, regardless of the exact track of Dorian’s center,” the hurricane center said.

The Capital Weather Gang reported that the severity of the storm’s impact will depend on how closely the storm winds up tracking to the coast.

Flash flooding was expected to become increasingly possible across coastal Georgia and the eastern Carolinas from Wednesday night through Friday, the hurricane center said. And “significant, life-threatening, flash flooding” is expected in the Carolinas, the hurricane center warned.

— Mark Berman

The Coast Guard dispatches cutters to help: ‘There are still people to be saved.’

KEY WEST, Fla. — Since the storm began, hundreds of distress calls seeking aid for people in the Bahamas have come in to the U.S. Coast Guard.

On Tuesday, the Coast Guard airlifted 19 people on Tuesday from a clinic in Marsh Harbor on Abaco Island to a medical facility in Nassau.

“The magnitude of destruction is catastrophic,” said Lt. Cmdr. Kristopher Ensley, the captain of the Paul Clark, one of nine Coast Guard cutters heading to the Bahamas to provide disaster relief and humanitarian assistance. “It’s tragic. We are going there to help. This is part of what the Coast Guard does. We save lives.”

“There are still people to be saved,” he added, emphasizing that the agency was assisting the Bahamian government, which is leading the response effort.



An aerial view of houses in the Bahamas from a Coast Guard Elizabeth City C-130 aircraft after Hurricane Dorian shifted north, Tuesday. (Adam Stanton/US Coast Guard via Getty Images) (Handout/Getty Images)

On Wednesday morning, several cutters headed to Miami to refuel and load pallets of plastic sheeting, one of the most needed supplies for shelter. The skies were clear, and the seas were still expected to be choppy with the storm roiling the Atlantic.

Although the Coast Guard routinely patrols near the Bahamas, especially the nearby areas of Bimini and Freeport, rescuers faced many unknowns Wednesday. Storm surges meant coastal depths were unpredictable.

Aerial photos showed that much of the debris landed in the ocean, possibly including parts of roofs, buildings and submerged boats. On a normal day, the charts might show a certain depth along the shore, but with the storm surges, coasts might be much higher, and boats may be submerged under the water

“You don´t really know what to expect,” said Ardy Effendi, executive officer of the Paul Clark cutter, who is originally from Pittsfield, Mass. “We can´t just push through a lot of debris.”

— Maria Sacchetti

[A storm chaser went silent as Dorian slammed the Bahamas. He reemerged with a harrowing story.]

In the Bahamas, the ocean became a bulldozer

While millions of Americans waited to see what impact Hurricane Dorian could bring, the storm’s terrifying power was on full display farther south.

The Bahamas took a direct hit, with nearly three out of four homes on Grand Bahama left underwater. On the island of Great Abaco, the storm left behind a debris field. Neighborhoods were flattened and homes turned to rubble.

Officials said the death toll had risen to at least seven, but they expected that this number would increase as authorities made it to damaged areas. Read more here.

— Mark Berman
description: The storm could bring a dangerous combination of wind, rain and storm surges to Georgia and the Carolinas, forecasters say.
authors: Mark Berman Covers National News For The Washington Post. He Has Been At The Post Since
